page.name: Steps to refine your goals statements
page.intro: Remember that your goal statements need to be specific enough to ensure change in teaching practice. View the following resource to help you set specific and measurable goal statements.
page.content:
Refining Statements about Goals (or Objectives)

Some of your goal statements (Topic 5) may not be specific enough to ensure a change in behavior (i.e., enhanced teaching). You may find this additional resource of help to you. When we think about goals (or about objectives)—whether they are related to academic pursuits or to personal goals, it’s helpful to think about the ABCDs of goal-setting or objective writing. The TEAL online course on effective lesson planning visits this topic in greater detail, including a discussion of the difference between goals and objectives. For now, consider the ABCDs of goal- or objective-setting (described by Heinlich, Molenda, Russell, & Smaldino [1996] in Instructional Media and Technologies for Learning. Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Merrill).

Audience: The students that the objective is written for. NOTE: In writing a goal for your own professional growth, the audience is you.  

Behavior: The verb that describes what the audience will be able to do. 

Condition: The circumstances under which the audience will perform the behavior

Degree: Acceptable performance

Examples of objectives for our students:

When one of their children is ill (condition), ESL students (audience) will be able to phone the school office to report their child’s absence (behavior) with 90% accuracy (degree).

Given the dimensions of each room on a house floor plan (condition), ABE students (audience) will be able to calculate the number of square yards of carpeting required for each room (behavior) with 90% accuracy (degree).

Example of a goal for ourselves as teachers:

When introducing my students to new content knowledge or skills (condition), I (audience) will model one or more formative assessment strategies (behavior) and provide guided practice and gradual release for my students (behavior) until they can perform the skill independently (degree).

***Please revisit your goal (Topic 5 of this course) and edit your goal, as needed, to be more specific and to reflect the ABCDs. The course facilitator will provide feedback and support, as needed.

Thank you!
